I think you quote the great, old physicist Freeman Dyson. He‚Äôs always had this line I love, which is, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a believing Christian, but I‚Äôm a practicing Christian.‚Äù

But then there is also this paradox that we are so often made by what would break us. It‚Äôs not overcoming it. It‚Äôs not beyond it. It‚Äôs not in spite of it. What goes wrong doesn‚Äôt have to define us; wisdom is walking through whatever darkness, whatever hardship, whatever imperfection and unexpected catastrophes or the like, the huge and the ordinary losses of any life, walking through those and integrating them into wholeness on the other side. That you‚Äôre whole and healed, not fixed. Not in spite of those things, but because of how you have let them be part of you.

I never use the word optimism. And it‚Äôs also an action. It‚Äôs something you put into practice. We‚Äôre learning through neuroscience that what you practice you become. And that goes for being more patient, being more hopeful, being more compassionate just like it goes for any other skill.

And so I think you can choose to be hopeful, which is a more courageous choice than cynicism. I mean, cynicism is really easy. It‚Äôs never surprised or disappointed. And doesn‚Äôt lift a finger to change anything.
